speakers.name: Elia Schito
speakers.bio: Ruby hacker and one of the main Opal.rb contributors

speakers.name: Barbara Fusińska
speakers.bio: Barbara is a software developer and mentor to inspiring developers. Working with a range of different companies, Barbara gained experience with team dynamics. This has lead to her strong belief in shaping a proper working environment. She trusts this allows high-functional teams to reach their full qualities. Alongside building passionate teams, Barbara enjoys collaborating around architectures.

speakers.name: Wojciech Ziniewicz
speakers.bio: Wojtek is a generalist and environment-oriented software developer. His team works on development of (probably) largest non-robotics, open source project implemented in ROS called Liquid Galaxy, which his company develops on behalf of Google.

speakers.name: Sander van der Burg
speakers.bio: Sander van der Burg is a software engineer and researcher specialized in software deployment and configuration management. He is a contributor to the NixOS project since 2007 and the author of Disnix: a toolset for deploying service-oriented systems. In addition to deployment, he has a broad interest in anything software engineering related, such as programming languages, distributed systems and testing.

speakers.name: Kacper Walanus
speakers.bio: Kacper graduated in philosophy. For him programming was a hobby, which turned out to be what he loves most. Works as a developer for six years now, currently for Oxford Valuation Partners. He likes teaching and has experience in passing knowledge. Functional programming, open source and SOLID principles fan.

speakers.name: Peter Bhat Harkins
speakers.bio: Peter Bhat Harkins is a senior software developer at DevMynd in Chicago, IL. As a developer and contractor he has built and maintained dozens of websites, experimenting all the way. He tweets as @pushcx and blogs at https://valent.io.

venues.name: University of Wrocław, Institute of Computer Science

data.title: The NixOS project and deploying systems declaratively
